Description: St Antony; standing in the left foreground, holding a book in his right hand and a bell and a staff with a large Tau cross in his left hand; at left a kneeling woman praying; at right a crippled man with crutches whose left arm is burning; suspended from a rail at the church at right a large number of votive offerings. Woodcut
Curator's comments: The man with the burning arm suffering from St Antony's fire or erysipelas, a bacterial skin infection usually affecting the limbs or face which St Antony was said to cure. Dodgson suggests that this print was part of an early series of male saints.
Bibliographic references: Pauli 1901-11 / Hans Sebald Beham: Ein Kritisches Verzeichniss seiner Kupferstiche Radirungen und Holzschnitte (891) (Alpha)
Hollstein / German engravings, etchings and woodcuts c.1400-1700 (891) (Alpha)
Dodgson 1903, 1911 / Catalogue of Early German and Flemish Woodcuts in the BM, 2 vols (I.465.115)
Associated names: Representation of: St Antony of Egypt
